bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to George E. Vincent, June 14, 1922

div1.p: Carter requests clarification of the veracity of a controversial study published by the Rockefeller Foundation, in 1921, regarding yellow fever and human experimentation.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to George E. Vincent, June 14, 1922
div1.opener:
I H. B
Vaccination
(Vincent)
V
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
June 14, 1922.
Mr. George E. Vincent, President
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Mr. Vincent:
div1.p:
On page 40 of “The Rockefeller Foundation, A Review for 1921,”
the statement is made: “In Peru, of a group of 50 non-immune sol-
diers who were being sent into an infected district, 25 were vac-
cinated and 25 were left unvaccinated. Twenty of the latter group
contracted yellow fever, while no case of the disease occurred among
members of the former.” Would you kindly give me the data on which
this is based?

The reason I ask is this: Dr. Noguchi made the same or a simi-
lar statement in a letter to me last fall, quoting Dr. White as
having been so told by Hanson. Hanson, under date of Jan. 24/22 has
"no recollection of the 50 soldiers of whom 25 were vaccinated and
25 unvaccinated. Nor is anything mentioned in the Report to the
Minister of War by Colonel Verne, the French officer, acting as
Medical Inspector of the Sanitary Service of the Peruvian Army: “Con-
cerning the yellow fever and the ravages produced among the troops
troops
in the Department of Lambayeque,” (translated). He had one would think
be apt to have done so if it occurred
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
